questions.text: Which of the following phase is usually not a mandatory regulatory requirement for drug approval?
questions.solution:
The phase 0/ microdosing stage is not mandatory and not clearly categorized by regulatory authorities yet.

Phase 0 studies

  • Very low doses of drugs, usually 1/100th of the estimated human dose or a maximum of 100 mcg is used.
  • They are done to obtain pharmacokinetics data in humans at a very early stage of drug development Preclinical, phase I, phase II, and phase III studies are mandatory for drug approval process (options a, c and d).

questions.text: High hepatic extraction ratio is not seen with
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin does not have high hepatic extraction ratio.

Drugs having high hepatic extraction:

  • Propranolol (option a)
  • Morphine (option b)
  • Pethidine
  • Salbutamol
  • Verapamil (option d)
  • Glyeryl trinitrate

Clinical correlate for drugs with high hepatic extraction:

  • Oral dose is very high when compared to parenteral dose to accommodate high hepatic extraction.
  • Oral dose has to be reduced in liver diseases.

questions.text: Decrease in Km value for an enzymatic reaction is seen with
questions.solution:
• Km of the enzyme is rate constant of the enzymatic reaction and defined as the substrate concentration at which the velocity reaches half of the maximum (Vmax).
  • Stimulation of an enzyme increases its affinity for the substrate resulting in lowering of rate constant (Km). Eg: Pyridoxine acts as a co-factor and stimulates decarboxylase activity.
Type of enzyme inhibition Km value
Enzyme stimulation Decreased
Enzyme induction Unaltered
Competitive inhibition Increased
Noncompetitive inhibtion Unaltered

questions.text: What does I.P in the following indicate?
questions.solution:
The IP in the image indicates Indian Pharmacopoeia

  • Pharmacopoeia contains the description of chemical structure, assay methods, solubility, standards of purity and other information regarding manufacturing of medicines.
  • They are useful to drug manufacturers and regulatory authorities. It indicates that the standards present in the mentioned pharmacopoeia are followed.

Examples of pharmacopoeia:

  • IP: Indian Pharmacopoeia
  • BP: British Pharmacopoeia
  • USP: United States Pharmacopoeia

questions.text:
The image below shows the metabolic pathways of levodopa in the periphery and brain. Identify the drug that corresponds to the action of A in the following

COMT - Catechol-O-methyl transferase

DDC - Dopa decarboxylase

3-OMD - 3-O-methyldopa

BBB - Blood-brain barrier

MAO - Monoamine oxidase

3-MT - 3-methoxytyramine

DOPAC - Dihydroxy phenylacetic acid

HVA - Homovanillic acid
questions.solution:
The drug that corresponds to the action of A is tolcapone.

Tolcapone is an anti-parkinsonism drug that acts by inhibiting COMT enzyme and is an adjuvant to levodopa-carbidopa in advanced parkinsonism with motor fluctuations. It acts as an adjuvant by prolonging the half-life of levodopa. COMT inhibitors are used to smoothen the 'wearing off' as well as increase the 'on' time and decrease the 'off' time and thus allowing to reduce the dose of levodopa. Another drug in the same class is entacapone.

Parkinsonism is an extrapyramidal disorder and is characterized by rigidity, tremor, and hypokinesia. It occurs due to degeneration of substantia nigra and the nigrostriatal tract causing a deficiency of dopamine.  

Other options:

Options A and B: Benserazide and carbidopa are peripheral (extracerebral) dopa decarboxylase inhibitors and do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier or inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine. 

Option C: Selegiline is an MAO-B inhibitor and at low doses retards the intracerebral degradation of dopamine.

The image below shows the various mechanisms by which different drugs show anti-parkinsonian action.

Related Pearl: Medical treatment of Parkinson's disease

Increase dopaminergic action Anti cholinergics

Dopamine precursor       

 Anti muscarinic
Levodopa Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl)
Dopa decarboxylase inhibitor Benztropine
Carbedopa Procyclidine
Benserazide H1 antagonist
Dopamine agonist-Ergot derivatives Promethazine
Bromocriptine Orphenadrine
Cabergoline Diphenhydramine
Pergolide  
Lisuride  
Dopamine agonist-Non ergot derivatives  
Ropinirole  
Pramipexole  
Rotigotine  
Apomorphine  
Dopamine facilitator  
Amantadine  
MAO-B inhibitor  
Selegiline  
Rasagiline  
COMT inhibitor  
Tolcapone  
Entacapone

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of vasopressin secretion?
questions.solution:
Ethanol consumption inhibits vasopressin secretion from posterior pituitary gland.

Drugs inhibiting or decreasing vasopressin release

Stimulating vasopressin release Inhibiting vasopressin release

Vincristine

Cyclophoshamide

Nicotine

Tricyclic antidepressants

Epinephrine

High doses of morphine

Ethanol

Phenytoin

Glucocorticoids

Haloperidol

Fluphenazine

Promethazine

Low doses of morphine

 

 

Remember

Lithium: inhibits renal effects of vasopressin but enhances central vasopressin secretion Carbamazepine: produces antidiuresis in central diabetes insipidus through renal action; but inhibits central vasopressin secretion

questions.text: Which of the following is the first FDA approved drug for obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
Clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that was the first approved drug for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

The following SSRIs have also been approved by the US FDA or use in OCD:

  • Fluoxetine
  • Fluvoxamine
  • Paroxetine (Paxil)
  • Sertraline (Zoloft) 
  • Citalopram

questions.text: An infant presents with the following features shown in the image below. On examination, microcephaly and hypoplasia of  distal phalanges are also found. The most likely medication that would have resulted in the above deformity is
questions.solution:
Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome

  • Digital hypoplasia
  • Microcephaly
  • Cleft lip, cleft palate and other minor craniofacial abnormalities

questions.text: The main lipid abnormality associated with atypical antipsychotics use is
questions.solution:
Atypical antipsychotics are associated with dyslipidemia, particularly hypertriglyceridemia.

Metabolic abnormalities associated with atypical antipsychotics.

  • Increased weight
  • Dyslipidemia
  • New-onset type 2 DM
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis

Atypical agents classified according to their metabolic risk potential

  • Highest: clozapine, olanzapine
  • Immediate: quetiapine, risperidone, paliperidone
  • Least: Aripiprazole, ziprasidone, iloperidone, asenapine

questions.text: The following effect of chronic ethanol consumption might increase the risk of acetaminophen induced hepatotoxicity
questions.solution:
Chronic ethanol consumption induces hepatic CYP enzymes (CYP2E1) that result in increased formation of hepatotoxic metabolite from acetaminophen.

Acetaminophen metabolism:

  • Major pathway: glucuronidation into inactive metabolites.
  • Minor pathway: CYP2E1 conversion into N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) which is a hepatotoxic metabolite.
  • Chronic ethanol consumption induces CYP2E1 enzyme resulting in increased formation of  NAPQI resulting in hepatotoxicity at less than toxic doses of acetaminophen.

questions.text: Complication that is not associated with metformin use
questions.solution:
• Metformin use is not associated with infertility.
  • On the contrary, it can cause ovulation and fertility in some infertile women with polycystic ovarian disease. Lactic acidosis is a rare and serious side effect of  metformin (option a).
  • Metformin can interfere with the absorption of vitamin B12 and cause vitamin B12 deficiency, but the incidence is rare (option b).
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances like abdominal pain, anorexia, bloating and others are common especially during initiation of therapy. Most of them subside with time (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a short acting insulin analog?
questions.solution:
Glargine is a long acting insulin analog.

Long acting insulin analogs (GlaDeD)

  • Glargine
  • Detemir
  • Degludec

Short acting insulin analogs (AsLi Glu)

  • As: Aspart
  • Li: Lispro
  • Glu: Glulisine

questions.text: The following statement is not true about sotalol

choices.text: It prolongs action potential duration throughout the heart
It is a cardioselective beta blocker
It is excreted primarily through kidneys
Torsades de pointes is a common side effect

questions.solution:
• Sotalol is a non selective beta blocker.
  • It has additional class III antiarrhythmic properties and thus prolongs the APD as well as the QT interval (option b). So it has propensity to cause Torsades de pointes. (option d).
  • Torsades de pointes incidence is around 1.5-2% and is dose dependent.
  • Sotalol is a lipid insoluble beta blocker and thus excreted primarily by the kidneys (option c).
  • Other lipid insoluble beta blockers are atenolol and nadolol.

questions.text: Hypocalcemia is seen more commonly with
questions.solution:
Loop diuretics decreases calcium reabsorption and can result in hypocalcemia

Loop diuretics by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter decreases calcium and magnesium reabsorption by abolishing the transepithelial potential difference that is the dominant force for these cations reabsorption.

Thiazide diuretics decrease excretion of calcium and can result in hypercalcemia (option a).

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors does not alter calcium levels (option c).

Acute effects of different diuretics on excretion of different electrolytes:

Diuretics Sodium Potassium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑↑ ↑
Thiazides ↑↑ ↑
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓

questions.text: T-type calcium channels are blocked by
questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is an antiepileptic that acts through selective suppression of T-type calcium channels. It is indicated in the treatment of absence seizures.

Types of calcium channels and their blockers:

  • L type: Verapamil, diltiazem, dihydropiridines
  • T type: Flunarizine, ethosuximide, mibefradil
  • N type: Gabapentin, ziconotide
  • P/Q type: Omega agatoxin IVa
  • R type: SNX-482, Omega agatoxin IIIa

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug?
questions.solution:
Lisinopril is the lysine derivative of enalaprilat (active form of enalapril).

All ACE inhibitors are prodrugs except lisinopril and captopril (option a).

Examples of prodrugs:

  • Prednisone
  • Levodopa
  • ACE inhibitors (except lisinopril and captopril)
  • Sulfasalazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Clopidogrel

questions.text: Which of the following is cholesterol absorption inhibitor?
questions.solution:
• Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor.
  • It interferes with a specific cholesterol transport protein (NPC1L1) in intestinal mucosa and decreases cholesterol absorption.
  • Cholestyramine and colesevelam are bile acid sequestrants.
  • Saroglitazar is a dual PPAR agonist approved for diabetic dyslipidemia in India.

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9 that is used in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE. It is approved for use in patients with asthma with elevated levels of circulating IgE.

Option C: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF. It is approved for use in patients with metastatic colorectal cancers and wet age-related macular degeneration (intravitreal administration).

Option D: Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4 integrin. It prevents α4β1 interaction with VCAM-1, thus restricting T-cell diapedesis into the brain. It is approved for use in multiple sclerosis. The use of natalizumab in a patient requires checking for antibodies against the JC virus. The presence of these antibodies indicates a latent infection, and is a contraindication to the use of natalizumab. Natalizumab can cause JC-virus antibody-positive patients to develop multifocal leukoencephalopathy. 

Note: Vedolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that prevents only α4β7 interaction and is approved for use in Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Recombinant interleukin 11 that is used in thrombocytopenia is
questions.solution:
• Oprelvekin is a recombinant interleukin 11 preparation.
  • It stimulates thrombopoiesis and is indicated in prevention of thrombocytopenia associated with antineoplastic agents.
  • Romiplostim and eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonist that are used in chronic immune thrombocytopenia (options a and b).

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct thrombin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is an oral anticoagulant that inhibits thrombin directly.

Oral factor Xa inhibitors (have “xa” in their names)

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban

Idarucizumab is an antidote for dabigatran.  It is a monocloncal antibody against dabigatran that binds dabigatran more avidly than thrombin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a GPIIb/IIIa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Cangrelor is an adenosine analog that binds reversibly to P2Y12 receptors and inhibits it.

GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors:

  • Eptifibatide
  • Abciximab: highest incidence of thrombocytopenia
  • Tirofiban

questions.text: The following side effect in a young male patient can be due to
questions.solution:
• Cimetidine displaces dihydrotestosterone from its cytoplasmic receptor, increases the plasma prolactin and inhibits the degradation of estradiol by liver.
  • High doses of cimetidine given for a long time can cause gynaecomastia in males and galactorrhea in females.
  • Other H2 blockers do not share this property (options a, c and d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a long acting beta 2 agonist (LABA)?
questions.solution:
Pirbuterol is a short acting beta 2 agonist (SABA).

Long acting beta 2 agonists:

  • Salmeterol
  • Formoterol
  • Arformoterol

questions.text: Mechanism of action of tamoxifen is

choices.text: Has partial agonist and antagonist action on estrogen receptors
Inhibition of FSH and LH release from the pituitary

questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. It has both agonist and antagonist action on estrogen receptors.

It has potent antiestrogenic effects in breast tissues.

Estrogenic agonist action is seen in

  • Endometrium: endometrial hypertrophy, vaginal bleeding and endometrial cancer.
  • Coagulation system: thromboembolism risk.
  • Bone metabolism: increase in bone mineral density.
  • Liver: alteration of blood lipid profile.

questions.text: Shortest acting acetylcholine esterase enzyme inhibitor among the following is
questions.solution:
• Edrophonium attaches reversibly to choline subsite of the active esteric site.
  • It does not form any covalent bond with the enzyme and it has a rapid renal elimination due to its quaternary structure making it a very short acting drug (5-20 min).
  • Edrophonium is used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis because of the short duration of action Neostigmine, physostigmine and pyridostigmine have longer duration of action (options a,b and c).
  • They bind to both esteric and anionic site of the AChE enzyme and carbamylate the enzyme.
  • Carbamylated enzyme is hydrolysed slowly resulting in reversible but longer acting inhibition of AChE.

questions.text: Synaptic transmission in sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia is predominantly

choices.text: Cholinergic in parasympathetic, adrenergic in sympathetic
Cholinergic in parasympathetic, dopaminergic in sympathetic
Cholinergic in both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia
Adrenergic in both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia

questions.solution:
• Acetylcholine is the major neurotransmitter in both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia innervated by preganglionic autonomic nerves. Therefore, both the ganglia have cholinergic transmission. 
  • The primary rapid depolarization is brought about by Nn type of nicotinic cholinergic receptors.
  • Subsidiary receptors like M1, M2, adrenergic, dopaminergic can modulate the primary response.

questions.text: Beta 3 agonist indicated for treatment of overactive bladder
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a beta 3 agonist that is indicated for the treatment of overactive bladder.

Stimulation of beta 3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in overactive bladder.

Oxybutynin, Solifenacin, darifenacin and Fesoterodine are anticholinergics that are used in the treatment of overactive bladder.

questions.text: Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with high affinity to
questions.solution:
• Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist that has high affinity to M3 receptors in salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • It has fewer side effects than non-selective pilocarpine.
  • It is indicated as a sialagogue in Sjogren’s syndrome.

questions.text: The “Vasomotor reversal of Dale” phenomenon is seen with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The vasomotor reversal of Dale is seen with adrenaline when an alpha blocker like phentolamine has been previously administered.

Rapid IV injection of adrenaline produces a marked increase in both systolic as well as diastolic BP. This occurs because at high concentrations α response predominates and vasoconstriction occurs. As the concentration declines, adrenaline is not able to act on α receptors but continues to act on β2 receptors.

When an α blocker has been given and then adrenaline is injected, only a fall in BP instead of an initial rise is seen, an effect first described by Dale and hence called vasomotor reversal of Dale. This is due to adrenaline's action only on β2 receptors, which are not blocked by phentolamine.

Noradrenaline and dopamine lack beta 2 action, and vasomotor reversal of the Dale phenomenon is not seen with them.

questions.text: Which of the following has higher alpha 1A receptor selective blocking activity?
questions.solution:
Both tamsulosin and silodosin have higher alpha 1A selectivity over alpha 1B receptors.

Tamsulosin is an alpha 1A/1D selective blocker.

Selective alpha 1A vs. non-selective alpha 1 blockers:

Advantage:

  • Less interference with blood pressure
  • Lower incidence of dizziness and orthostatic hypotension

Disadvantage:

  • Higher incidence of abnormal ejaculation or retrograde ejaculation

Prazosin is a non-selective alpha 1 blocker; it has equal selectivity for alpha 1A, 1B and 1D receptors  (option a).

questions.text: Inhibition of fibrinolysis is caused by
questions.solution:
• Epsilon amino caproic acid binds lysine-binding site of plasmin and inhibits plasmin-induced fibrinolysis.
  • Streptokinase is a plasminogen activator that results in fibrinolysis (option a).
  • Heparin is an anticoagulant, whereas protamine is an antidote to heparin (options c and d).

questions.text: H3 receptor agonists exhibits
questions.solution:
H3 receptors are predominantly auto receptors that decrease histamine release and antagonize the actions of histamine.

Therefore, H3 receptor agonists decrease H1 mediated gastrin secretion.

H3 receptor agonist actions:

  • Negative chronotropic activity: modulatory activity on adrenergic neuronal terminals resulting in decreased NA release (option a)
  • Sedation due to decreased histamine release (option b)
  • Inhibition of histamine induced bronchoconstriction (option d)

questions.text: Hypertrichosis of eyelashes is seen with the following antiglaucoma agents
questions.solution:
Topical PGF2 alpha analogs are associated with hypertrichosis of eyelashes.

Bimatoprost is used in the topical treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis.

Adverse effects of  topical PGF2 alpha analogs:

  • Eyelash hypertrichosis
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Macular edema
  • Blurred vision

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of claudication pain of the left lower limb while walking. Which of the following phosphodiesterase inhibitors is indicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The history of claudication pain suggests a likely diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease and cilostazol is the phosphodiesterase inhibitor that is indicated in this condition.

Phosphodiesterase (PDE) is an enzyme that degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly. Therefore, phosphodiesterase inhibitors increase the concentration of cyclic nucleotides (cAMP and cGMP).

There are different classes of phosphodiesterase inhibitors of which cilostazol is a PDE-3 inhibitor. It increases intracellular cAMP in vascular smooth muscle and platelets leading to vasodilatory and antiaggregatory effects. This allows patients with intermittent claudication to have better walking distance. 

Other options:

Option A: Sildenafil and tadalafil are selective PDE-5 inhibitor and are used for pulmonary arterial hypertension and erectile dysfunction.

Option C: Theophylline is a non-specific phosphodiesterase inhibitor that causes bronchodilatation as well as decreases the release of inflammatory cytokines. It has limited use in the management of asthma due to various side effects.

Option D: Milrinone is a selective PDE - 3 inhibitor and is used as a short-term therapy in severe or refractory congestive heart failure. 

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

PDE inhibitors Drugs Clinical application

Non-selective PDE inhibitors

 

Methylated xanthines, Caffeine, Theophylline

Asthma, COPD
 

Pentoxifylline

Peripheral artery disease  
PDE 2 inhibitor

Anagrelide

 Essential thrombocytosis
PDE 3 inhibitor

Cilostazol

 Peripheral artery disease
 

Milrinone, Amrinone

 Cardiac failure  
PDE 4 inhibitor

Roflumilast

 COPD
 

Drotaverine

 Antispasmodic drug
PDE 5 inhibitor

Sildenafil, Vardenafil, Tadalafil (Also inhibit PDE6)

 Erectile dysfunction Pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: Sacubitril is a/an
questions.solution:
• Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor indicated for the management of CHF along with valsartan, an AT1 receptor antagonist (option b).
  • The combination has mortality benefits in CHF patients.
  • Neprilysin is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of atrial and brain natriuretic peptide. Inhibition of neprilysin results in increased natriuresis and other effects that are beneficial for CHF patients.

questions.text: Macrocyclic antibiotic indicated for the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is
questions.solution:
• Fidaxomicin is a narrow spectrum macrocyclic antibacterial active against Clostridium difficile.
  • Like macrolides (14/15 memebered ring), fidaxomicin has a large lactone ring consisting of 18 membered ring. But the mechanism of action is different.
  • It is bactericidal and acts by inhibiting protein synthesis through blockade of RNA polymerase.
  • It is indicated in the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea especially in recurrent cases.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs blocks the binding of gp120 HIV protein to the CCR5 receptor?
questions.solution:
Maraviroc blocks HIV envelope protein gp120 from binding to the CCR5 receptor. 

During the entry of the HIV virus into the host cell, gp120 anchors the virion to the host cell by binding to CD4. Further, gp120 binds to CCR5 chemokine receptors to stabilize the entire complex. Gp41 then mediates the fusion of the viral membrane with the cell membrane of the target cell. Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that is used for the treatment of HIV. Maraviroc binds to CCR5 receptors and prevents viral entry into the cell. 

Enfuvirtide (option A) is another entry inhibitor that binds to certain domains of gp41 HIV protein and prevents membrane fusion and viral entry into the cell. It is the only antiretroviral drug that is given parenterally (subcutaneous or intravenous). 

Lopinavir (option C) is a protease inhibitor. This class of drugs inhibits the viral protease that is essential for conversion of the inactive protein precursors into functional proteins.

Raltegravir (option D) is an integrase inhibitor. It prevents the formation of covalent bond — and thus the integration — of the HIV DNA and the host cell DNA.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Code

HIV Source Code

          PEP Recommendation

1

 1

 Not required

1

 2

 Recommended

2

 1

 Recommended

2

 2

 Recommended

3

 1/2

 Recommended

2/3

Not known

Consider PEP if HIV prevalence is high in the given population

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: All are true about cephalosporins except

choices.text: Cefazolin is a first generation parenteral cephalosporin
Cefixime has poor activity against Staph aureus
Cefoxitin has no activity against anaerobes

questions.solution:
Cefoxitin, cefmetazole and cefotetan are the second generation cephalosporins that are active against anaerobic bacteria (B fragilis).

Cefazolin is a first generation parenteral cephalosporin (option a).

Cefixime has poor activity against Staph aureus (option c).

Cephalosporins having antipseudomonal activity:

  • Cefoperazone (option b)
  • Ceftazidime
  • Cefepime
  • Cefpirome

questions.text: Mesna use reduces the toxicity associated with high doses of
questions.solution:
• Cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide release a urotoxic metabolite called acrolein in high-dose regimens.
  • Acrolein is responsible for severe hemorrhagic cystitis.
  • Mesna or 2-mercaptoethanesulfonate prevents hemorrhagic cystitis by binding acrolein.
  • Leucovorin is helpful in mitigating high dose methotrexate toxicity (option d).

questions.text: BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor is
questions.solution:
Nilotinib is an inhibitor of BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase.

BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors

  • Imatinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Nilotinib

Gefitinib and erlotinib competitively inhibits ATP binding at the active site of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase (options a and b). Afatinib binds covalently to EGFR and other related tyrosine kinase receptors and cause irreversible inhibition (option d).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease was given a diuretic intravenously. Following administration of the drug, she developed tinnitus and diminished hearing. Which of the following drugs was most likely given?
questions.solution:
Ethacrynic acid is the diuretic that was most likely given as it is commonly associated with ototoxicity.

Ototoxicity occurs with rapid intravenous infusion and the hearing impairment and deafness are usually reversible.

Ethacrynic acid should be used only in patients who are not able to tolerate other loop diuretics.

questions.text: All of the following agents act by intracellular receptors except ______
questions.solution:
Insulin receptors belong to the class of trans-membrane enzyme-linked receptors.

Transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors consist of a large extracellular ligand-binding domain. It is connected to an intracellular subunit having enzymatic property through a single transmembrane helical peptide chain. The enzyme on the cytosolic side is usually a protein kinase (tyrosine) or membrane-bound GC (guanylyl cyclase).

Physiological ligands for transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors are mostly growth factors and chemokines. Other receptors belonging to this class include:

  • Receptor tyrosine kinases - Growth factors (PDGF, EGF, VEGF); insulin
  • Membrane-bound GC - Natriuretic peptides
  • Receptor serine-threonine kinases - TGF-β 

Thyroid hormones, vitamin D, and steroids act via intracellular receptors. 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: The following acid-base abnormality is least likely to be associated with salicylate use at therapeutic or toxic doses
questions.solution:
Metabolic alkalosis is least likely to be associated with salicylate use at therapeutic or toxic doses. 

At therapeutic doses:  Salicylates stimulate respiratory center causing a fall in PCO2 leading to respiratory alkalosis. This is compensated by increased renal bicarbonate excretion. 

At higher (toxic) doses: Salicylates directly depress the respiration preventing the washout of CO2 causing a fall in blood pH. Since the concentration of HCO3- in already low in the plasma due to increased renal excretion, it leads to uncompensated respiratory acidosis.

Further, salicylates impair renal function leading to accumulation of sulfuric and phosphoric acids and accumulation of organic acids like pyruvic, lactic and acetoacetic acid. This together leads to metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following NSAIDs can commonly cause NSAID induced nephropathy?
questions.solution: Phenacetin, a para-amino phenal derivative was introduced in 1887 and was used extensively therafter. It was subsequently withdrawn due to its association with analgesic abuse nephropathy.

questions.text: Which among the following antihistaminic drugs has additional platelet-activating factor antagonistic property?
questions.solution:
Rupatadine is an antihistaminic drug that has additional platelet activating factor antagonistic property and is indicated in allergic rhinitis.

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) is involved in the pathophysiology of allergic rhinitis, asthma, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in prophylaxis of migraine?
questions.solution:
Beta blockers having intrinsic sympathomimetic activity like pindolol is not effective in prophylaxis of migraine.

Non-selective blockers like propranolol and timolol and cardioselective blockers like metoprolol, atenolol are effective in prophylaxis of migraine.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration recently approved Emgality (galcanezumab-gnlm) solution for injection for the treatment of episodic cluster headache in adults, it reduces the frequency of attacks .It was first approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

questions.text: Osteomalacia in phenytoin is due to:
questions.solution:
• Osteomalacia due to phenytoin use is attributed to both alteration in vitamin D and vitamin K metabolism.
  • Alteration in vitamin D metabolism and the attendant inhibition in intestinal reabsorption of Ca2+ contributes to hypocalcemia and osteomalacia.
  • The increase in vitamin K metabolism reduces the concentration of vitamin K-dependent proteins that are important for normal Ca2+ metabolism in bones. This is the reason why the osteomalacia due to phenytoin is not always ameliorated by the administration of vitamin D.
  • Gamma carboxylation of osteocalcin and other important activities in bone requires vitamin K.

questions.text: Which of the following is a carbamazepine analogue that has an advantage of once daily dosing?
questions.solution:
Eslicarbazepine acetate is an analog of carbamazepine that has the advantage of once-daily dosing. It is a prodrug and is rapidly converted to active licarbazepine.

Oxcarbazepine is an analog of carbamazepine that is also converted to licarbazepine. Oxcarbazepine does not have the advantage of once-daily dosing like eslicarbazepine acetate.

Dacarbazine is not a carbamazepine analog like the other drugs and is a chemotherapy medication used in the treatment of melanoma and Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: A college student on MAO inhibitor therapy for depression consumed two bottles of beer during a party. The next day he started experiencing severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He was taken to the casualty by his friends where his BP was recorded to be 180/110mmHg. Which of the following compounds would be responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a hypertensive crisis in a patient on MAO inhibitor therapy is suggestive of cheese reaction, which is seen after consumption of foods rich in tyramine (beer).

Tyramine is an indirect sympathomimetic. It induces the release of catecholamines from the neurons. Tyramine can be produced in high concentrations in protein-rich foods by decarboxylation of tyrosine during fermentation.

Normally tyramine is inactivated when taken orally because it is readily metabolized by MAO in the liver. In patients who are on MAO inhibitor therapy, the tyramine taken in the diet is not inactivated and results in its increased sympathomimetic effect resulting in elevated blood pressure, termed as hypertensive crisis or cheese reaction. Drug of choice for cheese reaction is IV phentolamine.

When MAO inhibitors are taken along with SSRI or TCA, it results in serotonin syndrome due to the overstimulation of 5HT receptors. The clinical features are a triad of:

  1. Cognitive effect - delirium, coma
  2. Autonomic effects- hypertension, tachycardia
  3. Somatic effects- myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremors

questions.text: Maximum hepatic enzyme inhibition is seen with ______
questions.solution:
Cimetidine causes maximum hepatic enzyme inhibition among the given options.

Cimetidine inhibits CYP enzymes like CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP2D6. It can interfere with the metabolism of drugs that are substrates of the above enzymes.

Ranitidine also interacts with CYP enzymes but the affinity is only 10% to that of cimetidine (Option A).

Famotidine and nizatidine are considered safer with respect to enzyme inhibition (Options C and D).
